title: How to Use Australian Native Plants to Grow a Hedge

steps.headline: Grow lily pilly as a hedge.
steps.description: This is a popular choice for a hedge. It has no obvious flowers but it does have berries and lovely colour changing leaves. It does serve well as a hedge provided it's kept well pruned.

steps.headline: Grow Australian plants with plenty of flowers.
Try a fragrant plant as a hedge.
steps.description: This can be especially lovely if the hedge is going to wind around your bedroom window area. Lemon myrtle makes a good choice for a fragrant native Australian hedge. Just be sure to keep it well pruned regularly or else it'll grow out of control, and zoom up anywhere from 3 to 20 meters (9.8 to 65.6 ft)!

text:
Grow lily pilly as a hedge. This is a popular choice for a hedge. It has no obvious flowers but it does have berries and lovely colour changing leaves. It does serve well as a hedge provided it's kept well pruned. Grow Australian plants with plenty of flowers. If you'd like a colourful hedge, there are several plants that will meet this need and grow into a sturdy hedge offering privacy: Try grevillea for a hedge. This has a range of differently coloured flowers to choose from. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/7/7f/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/aid1215226-v4-728px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Try banksias to form a hedge. The beautiful banksia flowers will make this an intriguing hedge. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/8/8b/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/aid1215226-v4-728px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Both of these plants offer plenty of protection to small native birds that like to hide in thickets. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/8/8d/Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/aid1215226-v4-728px-Use-Australian-Native-Plants-to-Grow-a-Hedge-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Try a fragrant plant as a hedge. This can be especially lovely if the hedge is going to wind around your bedroom window area. Lemon myrtle makes a good choice for a fragrant native Australian hedge. Just be sure to keep it well pruned regularly or else it'll grow out of control, and zoom up anywhere from 3 to 20 meters (9.8 to 65.6 ft)!
